伊拉娜·韦恩斯坦谈对冲基金的人才争夺战（播客）

播音员：这是彭博电台巴里·里索尔茨 (Barry Ritholtz) 主持的商业硕士节目。

BARRY RITHOLTZ，主持人，商业硕士：本周的播客中，我有一位特别的嘉宾。伊拉娜·韦恩斯坦 (Ilana Weinstein) 回来向我们讲述过去几年她一直在合作的所有竞争性招聘和超级明星人才的情况。对于许多对冲基金行业来说，2022 年无疑是充满挑战的一年，它确实区分了赢家和失败者。

她具有独特的优势，不仅可以了解对冲基金行业的表现，还可以了解如何成为优秀的 PM 和失败者。业内很少有人像她一样具有洞察力和影响力。我可以继续说下去，但我不想这样做，我只想说一下我与 IDW 的伊拉娜·韦恩斯坦 (Ilana Weinstein) 的对话。

IDW GROUP LLC 创始人兼首席执行官 ILANA WEINSTEIN： 谢谢巴里，也谢谢您的精彩介绍。

RITHOLTZ：嗯，很高兴你回来了，而且时机也很完美，因为对冲基金的世界里正在发生很多有趣的事情。但在我们开始之前，让我们先深入了解一下你的背景，我觉得这很有趣。

你从高盛到哈佛商学院再到波士顿咨询集团。您早期的职业规划是什么？你一生想做什么？

韦恩斯坦：当我在宾夕法尼亚大学时，我有一个想法，我想成为芭芭拉·沃尔特斯。这就是我的想法。所以我喜欢她作为开拓者的样子。她对人们进行了精彩的采访。她把其他人无法做到的人带到了谈判桌前。她没有接受“不”的回答。我只是觉得，这是她所体现并能够利用的一套非常酷、独特的技能。

我不知道。我的意思是，我正在研究 19 世纪文学。我的高级论文是关于达尔文主义和托马斯·哈代的。这些都不适合高盛。我最终来到高盛，真的是因为我不想去法学院，因为这就是英语和心理学专业所做的事情。

里索兹：当然。 –

韦恩斯坦：对吗？

所以，我也在大四中期跳槽到高盛，因为我错误地告诉面试我的人我可以立即开始。我已经完成了，我很快就完成了课程。巴里，我在大学时有点书呆子的感觉。

RITHOLTZ：你是在高盛和宾夕法尼亚大学工作了整整四年吗？还是在高盛和宾夕法尼亚大学担任双重职务？

韦恩斯坦：我大四那年担负着双重职责。嗯，我在大三结束时完成了课程，然后开始在高盛工作。我在大四开始时参加了一些有趣的课程，然后在大四中期开始在高盛工作。但这使我能够做的就是早点去哈佛商学院，因为我处于非周期状态。

我在商学院的时候真的很年轻。在这段时间内，他们希望您至少拥有五年的工作经验。所以我非常清楚自己没有太多经验。 BCG 确实是一种追赶的方式。就像获得 MBA 学位一样，我并不是想成为一名顾问，而是想了解不同的行业和不同类型的问题。

RITHOLTZ：那么是什么引导您进入金融人才方面呢？

韦恩斯坦：在高盛，你知道，我意识到我并不真正喜欢金融。我可以做这项工作。我的工作做得足够好，进入了一所优秀的商学院，但真正让我兴奋的是——这就是 90 年代的高盛，当时它是一家私人合伙企业，吸引了最杰出的人，一些最杰出和最聪明的人在世界上。与他们打交道并与他们一起工作非常充满活力。

你知道，在 BCG，甚至回到史岱文森高中，我发现每个人都很聪明。你知道，当我想要置身于一个真正靠一群超级聪明的人为生、向他们学习的环境中。我觉得我能最好地做出贡献的方式是结合我在 BCG 和高盛的经验。 BCG 正在真正深入研究推动行业和公司发展的因素——战略。高盛非常以交易为驱动力，帮助人们从这一方走向另一方，而不仅仅是给他们提供建议。这就是我觉得我可以做出贡献的方式。

RITHOLTZ：我知道我有天生的能力去寻找金融界一些最优秀、最聪明的阿尔法生成器。

韦恩斯坦：这是怎么发生的？我在 BCG 工作时，正值互联网泡沫变得越来越大。那是我大二的时候，我的全班同学都离开了，去加州创办了一家科技公司。我真的没有——那不是我的事。我对此不感兴趣。不是的，我对此并不热衷。所以我仍在试图弄清楚我的下一步是什么。别忘了我还很年轻。我当时二十多岁。所以我最终加入了一家大型猎头公司，因为我觉得我对现有的不同类型的问题以及如何通过人力资本解决这些问题有了更多的了解。这可能会让我对下一步想做的事情有一些功能上的了解。

加入他们后我发现我实际上非常擅长他们所做的事情。与此同时，互联网泡沫破灭了。他们的主要金融服务业务——银行业和股票——已经跌落悬崖。渗透进来的是所有的道具组。

我开始为其中一些团体工作，有点像对冲基金行业，只有这么多优秀且真正受控的团体，并且是最好的且真正控制该生态系统的团体。他们非常有俱乐部精神，他们最终推荐了我，我的生意从此呈指数级增长。他们会向我推荐一位。这些是这些自营团体所关注的第一类产品，非常复杂的金融工具。

因此，我们都在边走边学，仅仅凭借一次真正的搜索，它就让我成为了专家，因为没有其他人这样做，所以我从那里建立了我的业务。

RITHOLTZ：所以你在 2003 年创办了自己的公司 IDW。顺便说一句，恭喜你，那是 20 年前的事了，所以今年你要庆祝一个重要的周年纪念日。是什么让你决定我知道我要独自出去？

韦恩斯坦：这是一个重要的周年纪念日，考虑到对冲基金的平均寿命为三年，我对此并不掉以轻心。我不知道你是否意识到这一点。

RITHOLTZ：生命周期非常短，营业额巨大，而且不仅仅是高水位线。造成这种持续流失的因素有很多。

韦恩斯坦：没错。我独自出去是因为我真的只想专注于做我感兴趣的工作。我在这家更大的公司内建立了这项业务，主要与这些高辛烷值的道具团队合作，我觉得我可以随身携带它。他们并不真正关心。他们本身就是企业家。他们并不关心自己是一家拥有数百名员工、分布在许多办公室的大公司的一员。他们关心领域专业知识，这就是我提出来的。

RITHOLTZ：所以你提到了许多对冲基金的寿命是众所周知的短。这也是一个竞争异常激烈的领域，因此持久力确实很有价值。您经营自己的商店已经有二十年了。在一个以不长寿着称的空间里，长寿的秘诀是什么？

韦恩斯坦：让我来定义一下我们的工作，因为我觉得一个公平的误解可能是，作为一家招聘公司，我们的工作是帮助人们找到工作。这实际上不是我们所做的。我们与业内最领先的对冲基金创始人和人才合作，找出下一步发展方向，并让他们保持领先地位。

当您想到能够应对世界上最具影响力的对冲基金挑战的个人时，您会发现这些人都是最优秀的人。这些人不是通常会寻找的人。

因此，为了与他们互动，并不是要帮助他们找到工作。这确实为他们提供了他们尚不具备的信息和观点。因此，我希望我的公司能够在趋势、主题方面处于领先地位，并拥有这些人如果不与我们会面就无法理解的观点。我不在乎他们是否进行过交易。我认为，如果我们提出足够有力的理由，他们就会很聪明，如果有意义的话，他们会进行交易并做一些不同的事情。但每次会议我们都会学到更多，并且对下一个人来说我们会更有力量。

我给你举个例子。我们最近遇到了一位基金经理，他的基金正经历着一段艰难的时期。他们去年损失了 40 亿美元。这么大的高水印。今年他们又跌了。他对创始人对待他的方式感到非常满意。他说：“伊拉娜，我在那里已经有一段时间了。我实际上认为创始人对我非常公平。我没有亏钱。他向我保证今年一百万美元，明年一百万美元。”

与那些持有类似基金的人进行五次会议确实很有帮助，这些基金的损失也同样大，事实上，他们可能对这些损失负有更大的责任，并且能够告诉他，首先，你的基金，仅根据我的计算，就有2.5亿美元的管理费。所以我不确定这对创始人来说是否如此慷慨。第二，您可能有兴趣知道，这里有四到五个不同的基金处于相同的情况。创始人所做的就是保证他们的员工对损失负有比你更大的责任，是你所得到的损失的四到五倍。

所以这就是他脑子里开始有点不安的地方。然后我们上升到一个层次，讨论他是否正在学习使他在行业发展中处于领先地位的技能。

巴里，我想说，这是 20 年智慧的结合，是与无人能敌的最优秀人才交谈的结晶。

RITHOLTZ：所以我想重点关注这一点，因为你在那里提出了一些非常有趣的观点。当您提到商业智能时，实际上它是对您熟悉的数据的精明使用，但它不在彭博终端上，也没有公开列出，这些都是非常严格掌握的信息。

你可能会在一个独特的情况下看到很少有人看到的风景。这有多大的优势？

韦恩斯坦：这就是一切。

里索兹：这就是一切。真的。

韦恩斯坦：所以想一想，你很快乐，你做得非常好，或者至少你认为你很快乐。你知道，当我们处理完你的事情时，你可能不会那么高兴。

（笑声）

韦恩斯坦：但从任何人的标准来看，你都做得很好。这些都是很大的数字。我们采访过的一些人的薪酬接近九位数而不是八位数。

里索兹：哇。

韦恩斯坦：所以这实际上并不是关于被剥夺权利或痛苦或需要找工作。他们不需要交易。

里索兹：对。

韦恩斯坦：好吧，这并不像，你知道，你坐在卖方，是的，你知道，你在股票销售台，有人不需要与另一边的高盛进行交易。电话，但他们确实需要与某人进行交易。这些人不需要交易。他们来与我们会面的唯一原因是因为他们会学到一些东西，并且他们会带着一些观点离开，就像我刚才给你的例子，他们没有以前有过。这与我认为大多数招聘公司所做的甚至真正能够做到的动态非常不同。

RITHOLTZ：所以我知道你的工作与许多最大的对冲基金创始人密切相关。这不是“嘿，我需要填补一个座位。”让我们讨论一下我们想要采用或正在考虑采用的策略，以及我们如何将其落实到位并配备人员。

请告诉我们一些您所做的工作，这不仅仅是“嘿，我为新兴市场不良债务找到了合适的基金经理。”它比那复杂得多。

韦恩斯坦：还有更多。想想吧，巴里，当我们正在推动一艘战舰前进时。那并不那么容易。实际上，我认为您向我发送了这篇文章，因为我在短信中找到了您的名字，然后它就出现了。现在对冲基金比汉堡王还多，好吗？

RITHOLTZ：是的，没错，在全国范围内。

韦恩斯坦：你把它发给我了。

里索尔兹：是的。

韦恩斯坦：这些不像那些荒无人烟的小汉堡王。想想那些与我们合作的人，我不知道，他们是该领域快餐连锁店最大的特许经营权所有者。

RITHOLTZ：嗯，我在《华尔街日报》的专栏中读到了关于您的报道，那是在 2019 年大流行之前，您正在与 Point72 的史蒂夫·科恩 (Steve Cohen) 和 Citadel 的肯·格里芬 (Ken Griffin) 以及所有其他大型对冲基金进行交谈。我知道你不会透露你的客户，但《华尔街日报》肯定提到了这些。我想这些公司的创始人对他们想去的地方和想做的事情有着相当扎实的把握。您如何在战略方面与他们互动？他们对您的见解的接受程度如何？

韦恩斯坦：有时就像我所说的，在推动战舰前进方面，只是确保他们拥有适合其现有策略的最佳投资专业人士。正如我所说，这同样不是一件容易的事，因为门槛非常高，我们寻找的东西太多，而能够应对这一挑战的人却很少。

有时他们来找我们的想法是，你知道吗，有一个我们认为有意义的相邻策略。让我们考虑一下最好的方法。我们买基金吗？我们找到了我们认为可以筹集资金的人，并帮助他们进行计算。有时我会去找他们说：“我认为你们应该看看这个。”我刚刚和一位客户遇到过这种情况，他经营着一只非常大的基金，不是多经理基金，而是多策略基金。他和我一直在讨论如何让他的基金提升到一个新的水平，该基金已经非常大了，我的意思是非常大。

我们已经讨论过类似的事情，而且它是开放式的。他告诉我他正在经历的微积分，这就是我如何从现在的位置到达有意义的地方，比这要大得多。我们讨论了是否要更深入地研究现有战略、建立新业务、寻找可以在风险管理和投资流程方面为他提供更多帮助的人（几乎是联合首席信息官）。我和他进行了很多交谈，我说过，“我们需要退后一步，思考你真正需要什么”，因为这些是不同的技能，并且它们属于不同的人。但我也向他提出了一些想法。

激进主义又如何呢？那填空呢？他今天没有做但可能有意义并且相邻的事情，他正在探索所有这些事情。

RITHOLTZ：所以你正在与大型对冲基金创始人和业内其他经验丰富的人士进行此类对话。我不得不想象，惊喜时不时就会出现。当你与什么样的事物互动时，你会感到震惊，“哎呀，我没有预见到会发生这种事。”我打赌你一定有很多精彩的故事。

韦恩斯坦：我愿意，巴里。我有点感觉，你知道——

RITHOLTZ：你能在学校说话吗？或者——

韦恩斯坦：你必须等待这本书。

（笑声）

韦恩斯坦：也许有一天会有这样的一天。当我退休并以匿名身份发表文章时，我必须这样做。

RITHOLTZ：人们会明白的。

韦恩斯坦：他们可能会的。但无论如何，当我们到达那座桥时，我们就会跨过那座桥。

与人相处，总会有惊喜。这就是让我保持警惕的原因。这其中有太多的曲折。你认为你可以让某人在他们的生活中做好准备，他们有充分的理由应该辞职并去我们过去六个月一直为他们努力的方向，而他们最终留下来。

然后有些人就这样离开了，我认为要留住他们将是一场殊死搏斗。

里索兹：真的吗？

韦恩斯坦：但是你知道，建立我的业务对我来说是最令人惊讶的事情之一，这与我的客户无关，对于一家在行业中真正独特的利基市场告诉你，这只是一件有趣的事情。对冲基金行业是对的，我们为对冲基金行业招聘人员，我们的招聘水平我认为是不寻常的，为我们自己招聘是如此困难。

只是，这太难了，因为我们之前所了解的使我们与众不同的秘密武器的一部分，对我们来说，我们需要一个具有战略性、交易驱动、真正深入微观的人，你像所有人一样都提到过我们合并细节和信息，然后可以提升一个水平并弄清楚如何将其商业化。

RITHOLTZ：你在哪里可以找到这样的人？

韦恩斯坦：这太难了。我们通常从银行雇用人员。我喜欢几年的经验，这样我们就可以塑造他们并教授他们。更多的经验并不一定有帮助。他们只能通过接触和坐在座位上收集的信息来学习很多东西。

但这很难，真的很难。

RITHOLTZ：所以你提到了很多惊喜，没有震惊，它来自于人的因素。有哪些事情真正让你皱眉？是什么真正让你停下来？

韦恩斯坦：好故事有很多，巴里，但我要讲的一个故事是很早就讲的，希望如果主角自我认同的话，不会有人太推迟。那是 IDW 的第一年左右。我们正在与一位客户合作，他当时就是业内的知名人士，出色的对冲基金创始人，非常注重增长和卓越。我们第一次寻找他，是为了寻找信贷主管。我真的很想给他留下深刻的印象。经过多次尝试和错误后，我们找到了一个人，正如我之前所说，他并没有仔细观察，他就像是街上最大的农作物之一——信贷自营交易员。非凡的声誉。我不记得他是在贝尔斯登还是雷曼兄弟任职，但那是已经不复存在的银行之一。这不是他的错。但无论如何，在当时，这是一件大事。

没有兴趣参加谈判，但我解释了他应该参加的所有原因。选择性是一件很棒的事情。这是一个了不起的人。然后我很兴奋。安排会议。我们就说那是在收盘之后。那时大约是四、五点钟。我有点像看了一眼手机，等待它响起，听听这是一次多么精彩的会议。因为这个家伙就像一切一样。这就是我认为我们这次搜索想要的一切。

一小时后电话响了，是我的客户打来的。他说：“这种事永远不会再发生了。”

里索兹：哦，真的吗？

他这么说是什么意思？

作为一名女性企业家，我，你知道，作为一名女性，有些事情你确实需要解决，我想说，对于任何在生活中具有竞争优先事项的人来说，这可能都是正确的，无论是男性还是女性的主要照顾者儿童或年迈的父母或任何情况。但我只能从我自己的角度来说。我告诉人们的是，我告诉女性的是，你可以做所有事情，但不能同时做所有事情。

We were still doing a lot of work for the prop desks, again, the precursors to the hedge funds. And we were working with one of the most aggressive sell-side firms on the street, certainly with respect to its prop businesses. And they wanted to build their structured credit business. And we went through the whole resignation conversation. We prep people within an inch of their lives before they walk in and they resign. And I told him to expect that he was this was going to be his 15 minutes of fame. He was going to go in and they were going to put more and more senior people at the bank in front of him and make him feel like if he were to leave, the bank would careen off a cliff, which we both know is not the case. They were fine with all due respect. I said to him they were fine before you showed up and they'll be fine after. You're great but it's going to be fine.

And he sounded good, he sounded solid, he knew to resign to his boss and basically get out of there and shut down other conversations.

So I tell my client and everyone at this bank was involved from the CEO on down. This was a very important person to them and they wanted to make sure it got done. And I tell them I feel really good, he sounds great, we're going to get this done.

Goes in the next day, knows to call me an hour into resignation, which he does. He tells me, “Ilana, it's going well, but they want me to meet the head of global markets to explain my thinking.”

I said, “We talked about this.

RITHOLTZ: Right, walk out, you're done.

Anyway, you can imagine where this ends up going. He's in a conference room. That additional conversation manifests into 10 additional conversations. They're now trotting out the entire management committee of the bank in front of him. The head of the bank's getting involved. His phone is now off. My team is calling onto the desk. We're trying to get through to him any which way we can. It is impossible. Meanwhile, my client on the other side is going bonkers because we're now late into the afternoon. We can't reach him, and they're second guessing their decision. Do we have the right guy? Doesn't he know what he wants? Is this a leader? Blah, blah, blah. Doesn't he understand? You know, this couldn't be clearer, the reasons he should make this decision. If he's not out of there soon, Ilana, we're pulling the offer. So–

RITHOLTZ: Is it just inertia? People just get comfortable and don't want to move?

WEINSTEIN: I think people get comfortable and they feel like, again, it's economic loss aversion theory at work. They overweight everything that can go wrong and they really don't pay attention to if they make a move. They underweight what can go right and they're just not focused on the dire situation that they're in.

And when you're being deliberate about managing your career, you're asking, and I'm not suggesting people hop around for the sake of hopping around, but you do need to ask yourself the tough questions at various pivot points. And this isn't just true for hedge funds, it's true for any industry. How is my fund or firm performing? How am I evolving? Am I learning the skills I need in order to be effective going forward? Am I on a path to grow? Am I stagnating or am I increasing my value and optionality in the market? Am I being paid fairly?

And to the extent that they're not and they're just literally sticking their head under the covers and not thinking about these things, they really need to ask themselves why that's the case. It's the number one reason people flame out. They don't keep pressing forward, don't keep improving, don't keep learning.

RITHOLTZ: So that raises a really interesting question because you're suggesting that talent should be thinking about more than just salary and equity. RITHOLTZ: Matters, sure.

WEINSTEIN: Number two is autonomy. And even if it's not complete jurisdiction over the portfolio, increased ability to impact the results. Okay? So people should really want that and that sense of agency.

The second thing is clarity. Not the number per se, that's important, but clarity around how we get to that number.

RITHOLTZ: Meaning it's not a crazy calculation. You have an idea each month, each quarter, how you're personally doing the terms of –

RITHOLTZ: Do they matter at some of the larger hedge funds or are people wearing multiple hats doing the same job?

WEINSTEIN: What I mean is we define, different founders define those things differently. So I'll give you an example. We did a search about eight years ago for a well-known single manager, long short equity founder, who'd been around at that point for 20 years and had just had one of his most senior people depart. And what he told me he wanted was a partner. The guy was a partner. He wanted someone who, and he said he's willing to give this guy substantial points and would operate really as a PM alongside him.

I want someone who's going to be able to make decisions with me, help deploy capital, help size, help construct the portfolio, more of a PM than an analyst. And what I said to him is, “There's no one I can find you that has 20 years of working with you.” And the way that you evolved people, because everyone there was hired basically as a young analyst out of Goldman and then homegrown, he saw what people were capable of. They had wins with him over time, and then he gave them more and more responsibility.

So to go into the market and basically find what for him would be a stranger and put that person in at a senior level, I knew wasn't going to work. And in fact, what we ended up doing was putting in — It was a senior person, but it was someone who was less experienced, was really a senior analyst. was happy to have a seat at the table and be able to feed him ideas and over time morph into more of a PM or partner type role.

But PM means different things even among the multi-managers who do have that, you know, where that title really does mean they're giving somebody an allocation of capital and that person does have autonomy. In some places a PM is really, really, no, it's man, it's always managing capital but it might be a small amount of capital.

You might start with a paper book. It's like a mini PM, or a PM with training wheels. And you might be overseeing a very small team to start. In other places, we want somebody who can build a scale business out of the gate and can manage a lot of capital. And by the way, their definition of analysts may be different. There are places where being an analyst almost looks more like a PM. They are managing a significant amount of GMV. They do have a payout on that. Their definition of analysts may look, again, it may look more like mini PMs. So we really need to dig into these things and define what we're after.

And I would say for an analyst, that's idea generation, creativity, independent research, asking the right questions. For a PM, it's risk management, portfolio construction, hedging, sizing, the ability hopefully to build and manage a team.

And where we're looking for someone to build a strategy that's more like a founder. It's someone that we can raise capital around, potentially raise a fund around, and of course attract talent and also has a sense of what is needed with respect to technology and operations for their strategy. So different skill sets.

RITHOLTZ: I was going to say it sounds far more complex than I think a lot of people might assume looking in from the outside. How important is fit? How do you figure out, hey, this square peg is going to fit or won't fit into that round fund. How do you evaluate personalities on top of all these really challenging skill sets? WEINSTEIN: There are things we do to see how closely the candidate maps to what we will want them to do. We do case studies, idea pitches, mock portfolios, business plans. Those are all sort of the hoops we have them jump through. But then in addition, we do soft referencing as a firm. If you think of 20 years of meeting with the most talented people at every hedge fund, odds are if you're a candidate, Barry, I've met with five other people from your fund that have a point of view on you.正确的？ So we very quickly get a 360 on how people think, their velocity of ideas, their response time, when they spot an opportunity, their ability to commit capital, and how they systematize their process so it's scalable and repeatable.

These are all the things we're going to dig into in finding out about people. And I also love it when someone comes in with a clear sense of attribution. I don't think it's a great sign if someone has no idea what their P&L is. I get that often it's not tracked at many funds.

RITHOLTZ: Really? I'm shocked to hear that because —

WEINSTEIN: Not formally tracked.

RITHOLTZ: But you could still export your book to an Excel spreadsheet and say, “Here's where I am.”

WEINSTEIN: We're saying the same thing. I expect people to have done that. I expect people to have a clear sense of attribution. To the extent that they don't, it's not a good sign, is what I'm saying.

RITHOLTZ: No, I would not.

WEINSTEIN: But the best people come in, I mean, honestly, some of them come in with a huge spreadsheet, This is what I've contributed. And by the way, here are all the things I wanted to do that the founder didn't let me do and how I would have performed if they've let me.

RITHOLTZ: Right.

WEINSTEIN: Now I'm savvy enough after all these years to know and that if I add a little bit of a grain of salt and if I added up all of the returns of everyone we meet from fund A, B or C, it would probably be north of 300%. So you know, there's that. But I do think there is still something to a sense of ownership and directional truth.

And then the final thing I'd say to you is there's always a leap of faith. I don't care how much work both sides do, and we do a lot of work to have a strong sense that the person will be successful. There's always a leap of faith because we're talking about different founders, different definitions of success and failure, different investing style, different approaches to training and development. And I always tell the clients I'm working with that they have to lead with war stories. They have to lead with all the things that might have gone wrong early on when they recruit someone and how they help that person to get out of a hole and to go on and be successful. Because that's what's in the minds of people before they make a leap. What happens when things go south? How will I be treated?

And founders really need to, or whoever's doing the recruiting, and this is again any industry, you really need to lead with what constitutes failure. Losing money in and of itself, yes, you fail to make money, but why? How did you get yourself into that situation? So there's sort of like good failure, which is a learning experience and we think we can improve you, and let's define what is a situation where we think it actually isn't the right fit. You need to get people clarity.

RITHOLTZ: Makes sense. A good process will occasionally have a bad outcome and you can't just assume every good outcome is the result of a good process.

All right, so I only have you for a few more minutes. Let's jump to our favorite question that we ask all our guests, starting with what has been keeping you entertained over the past couple of years? What have you been doing either when we were locked down or just out and about revenge traveling?

WEINSTEIN: Revenge traveling. I took a fantastic trip with my son to Italy last summer.

RITHOLTZ: I do recall we were talking about that and we didn't know what was going to happen. There was a couple of variants. We were both talking about traveling last summer. Where'd you go in Italy?

WEINSTEIN: It's almost where didn't we go? We went everywhere. The only places we didn't go were Puglia. Am I pronouncing that correctly? Soft G, Puglia. And we didn't go to northern Italy.

RITHOLTZ: So I've never been to Lake Como and I want to check that out.

WEINSTEIN: Phenomenal.

RITHOLTZ: I haven't been to Milan, I haven't been to Modena, which is why I'd love to go.

WEINSTEIN: I have not been to Modena either. But for two foodies like us, that's worth hitting.

RITHOLTZ: I have a friend who did this private tour where instead of staying at hotels, you stay at people's houses and they cook dinner for you and it's grandma making the secret family recipe and he said he came home 20 pounds heavier.

WEINSTEIN: I'm sure.

RITHOLTZ: It was amazing. Let's talk about mentors. Who helped to shape your career?

WEINSTEIN: It's totally my parents.

RITHOLTZ: Really?

WEINSTEIN: I had amazing parents.

RITHOLTZ: What did your parents do?

WEINSTEIN: My father ran a small insurance brokerage so he was an entrepreneur but small. I mean he was this is your classic first-generation immigrant story.

RITHOLTZ: Right.

WEINSTEIN: My dad did grow up in the States. He was born and raised in Brooklyn, part of what we often term the greatest generation.

RITHOLTZ: Right.

WEINSTEIN: He volunteered to fight World War II. He was an amazingly patriotic person. He was a tail gunner for B-29s. They used to take us out. My parents used to take us out to airfields in the middle of nowhere to look at these old planes. Really hardworking guy. And I listened to all the issues that he would bring home and discuss with my mom, who's an amazingly smart woman. She can run circles around most people. And she was kind of the CEO of our family. She really pushed us to be our best. She helped my dad. She came here. She was a hidden child during the Holocaust.

RITHOLTZ: Oh really?

WEINSTEIN: It's a whole story unto itself. She came to Israel, then her family emigrated to Israel, and then she came to the United States, met my father, and they were, we didn't have much growing up. They just, they did the best they could in the way of giving us stuff, but there wasn't really a lot of material wealth that I grew up with, far from, but I had great parents who taught me the importance of, by example, through my father and my mom, just in terms of her wisdom, of constantly pressing forward.

And, you know, there wasn't a lot of room for whining in my house. She's, you know, she was in the Israeli army. She's tough. She's strong. My dad, again, great, wonderful man who's a phenomenal salesperson, but worked super hard. And I admired his resilience. And it was about pushing forward and not giving up. And that, I think, is that grit and perseverance. We don't really talk too much about that. I actually think it's one of the most important determinants of someone's success in life and also professionally.

RITHOLTZ: Grit and perseverance, good qualities to have.

Let's talk about books, what are some of your favorites? What are you reading right now?

WEINSTEIN: Well I love books that are about real life, could be a moment in time like Tom Wolfe type books, maybe the story is quote fiction, but loosely based on things that were happening then. or of course Michael Lewis, which is, those are real stories told in a highly entertaining way. The stuff I'm reading now is courtesy of my 18-year-old son who's gotten into the habit of buying his mom books that he thinks she might like, and he's hit it out of the jackpot every time.

RITHOLTZ: Really?

WEINSTEIN: Yeah, so now, thanks to Jordan, I'm reading, I think it's called “Ticking Clock.” It's by Ira Rosen, who was a producer for “60 Minutes,” and he bought me that because he knows I love the movie with “The Insider” with Russell Crowe, which was an expose, of course, on the tobacco industry, but also on the world of journalism. And the book is fascinating. It's like being in the newsroom. It's all the intrigue that went on behind the scenes. It's just– it's an — and it's so funny. He's just– he's like this reverent, no BS, awesome, engaging storyteller. Phenomenal.

And then the other book I'm reading that my son got for me is called “The Kings of New York” which is about really the New York skyline and the whole real estate industry. And again, told almost like a thriller in terms of how it unfolded, what all the inside baseball was and the rise and fall of a number of real estate dynasties.

RITHOLTZ: Really quite fascinating. Our final two questions, what sort of advice would you give to a recent college grad who is interested in a career in either hedge funds or talent scouting and recruiting.

WEINSTEIN: For anyone, the question is why do you want to do that? What is it? And if the answer for anything is because they think it's lucrative, that's not a good answer.

RITHOLTZ: Right. By the way, I've heard that time and again from people sitting in that seat. Hey, if you're in this game for the money alone, you're going to be disappointed.

WEINSTEIN: It's important to try, if you know what you want to do, that's great. I have a candidate right now who's been investing in biotech since he was 13. Yes, and so he knows what he wants to do. And I learned that because I said what you studied in college was really interesting. You were pre-med, which is tough enough, and also studying business. Like how did you know back then? He's like, I just knew. I knew I wasn't going to be a doctor. I was fascinated by biotech, but I wanted to come at it from the investing angle.

To the extent you don't really know, I think it's so important to try different things. To your opening questions to me, I didn't know. And I learned through all of my experiences, what I liked, what I was best at, and just as valuable, what I didn't like, and what I felt, you know, I wasn't a natural at.

I think it's okay to go on a bit of a journey early on, but you have to be on that journey aggressively. And meaning if what you're doing is not something that really is singing or speaking to you, you have to keep moving forward till you figure it out.

RITHOLTZ: So purposefully —

WEINSTEIN: Purposefully, you can then lock in and really build something.

RITHOLTZ: Really interesting. And our final question, what do you know about the world of investing today, hedge funds, talent recruitment that you wish you knew 20 years ago when you first launched IDW?

WEINSTEIN: I'll use your word purposefully. It's really important for founders to manage their team purposefully, meaning you have to give people room to fail, but you also have to cut when it makes sense. And I think a lot of founders are afraid to do that because how will it look to LPs? It's uncomfortable to have to do those, to have to manage people out. What will it do to our culture? But a killer culturally is to be someplace where it becomes a hotbed for mediocrity.

And so —

RITHOLTZ: A hotbed for mediocrity, meaning you just start accumulating key players.

WEINSTEIN: You just start accumulating deadwood. And it becomes, and I hear this time and again where people say, you know, where they haven't really been paid that well, well, there's this kind of smoothing effect that goes on at our firm where maybe I'm not paid as well as I should be, but in down, you know, when things don't go that well at the firm, I also am not hit as hard perhaps as other places.

And I said, can we take a step back and look at your personal P&L history? For the most part, you've been a rock star every year you've been there.

RITHOLTZ: Why you hedging —

WEINSTEIN: Why on earth are you giving yourself an artificial ceiling here? And why are you, for someone who can never put up the goods, that's a great paradigm. Why is it for you? And so I think again, it all comes back to being front-footed as talent, but also as an institution in managing for growth aggressively.

如果您知道De Tomaso ，那可能是因为Pantera 。这款中置发动机、后轮驱动的跑车是意大利设计与底特律肌肉的完美结合。车身由 Carrozzeria Ghia 制造，动力装置为福特 V8。这是德托马索最受欢迎的汽车，1971 年至 1992 年间生产了 7,000 多辆。

2023 年上半年即将结束，其强度令当地人震惊。为什么？因为几乎没有人预见到这次反弹的到来。 1

截至目前，这些指数明显高于 2023 年 1 月 1 日的水平：纳斯达克 100 指数上涨超过 38%，标准普尔 500 指数上涨约 15.5%，罗素 2000 小型股指数上涨近 7% 。这些数字将使这一年的时间减少一半。

根据昨天关于信仰体系和思维过程的讨论来考虑这些收获，只是这一次，不是指反疫苗者和叛乱分子，而是想想你从基金经理、经济学家、策略师和各种专家那里听到的所有内容，他们自由地发表了意见2023 年这个市场将走向何方。

为什么他们如此确信自己知道会发生什么？他们的来源是什么？他们的流程？他们有没有考虑过他们可能错了的可能性？

更重要的是，您是否依赖这些人来传达您的投资观点？他们最近的业绩记录让您记忆犹新，您将来还会依赖他们吗？

错过了大涨之后，这群人现在正忙着满头大汗地跑来跑去，大喊着这一举动是多么不可持续——他们似乎觉得股票太贵了，尽管人们一定想知道他们是否也会有同样的感觉如果他们参加集会，而不是在场边大喊大叫，那就更好了。

或许，从背景来看，我们可能会在比年初至今更广泛的时间范围内考虑这些指数：例如，回顾两年，我们发现 2023 年迄今的大部分涨幅只是 2022 年跌幅的恢复，因为利率上涨，对利润崩溃的担忧开始显现。

如上面的 2 年期图表所示，纳斯达克 100 指数上涨超过 4%，标准普尔 500 指数上涨约 3.4%，罗素 2000 指数下跌 18%；这些都不是值得庆祝的理由。然而，这正是过去两年美国股市给你带来的结果。

在回撤回升的背景下，从低点反弹看起来非常不同。
